resources.string: Please make sure you enter an email address and password!
Account successfully created! You can now Login.
Please make sure you enter an email address and password!

Click the SUBSCRIBE TO ALERTS button below to get alerts on: 

 Reminder to register,
 Election day,
 Reminder to vote.

Voting provides an opportunity to choose a leader of your choice 

 Voting provides an opportunity to vie in elections. By law, only registered voters are allowed to vie for elections. 

 You safeguard your rights and freedoms as provided for in the constitution. 

 You give legitimacy to leaders. By electing their leaders, voters give their consent to be led by whoever they have chosen and to reject those who fail to sufficiently represent their interests.
Present your voters card and ID
The clerk captures your identity details
Confirm your identity details are correct
You are given stamped ballot papers
Place your fingers on the fingerprint reader
Have your passport size photo taken and confirm it is clear
Sign IEBC reference book and take registration slip. Leave registration centre.
Left small finger marked with ink
To see the welcome slider again, goto Settings -> apps -> welcome slider -> clear data

To Vote, you must: 
 	• be a Kenyan citizen 
	• be at least 18 years old and above 
	• be Registered as a Voter

 The polling station is where you vote.

 Inside the polling station is the Presiding Officer. He or she will inform you about the proper identification to use and the procedure to follow.

 You will show your national ID or my valid Passport, which ever you used to register. 

 The voting screen or booth is a private place in the polling station where you mark your ballot.

 The ballot box is where you put your marked ballot paper after you make your choice.

As a voter, I will have the right to:

 a) An orderly peaceful election conducted in accordance with laid down procedures.

 b) Know the candidates and, through their campaigns, what they stand for.

 c) Choose a candidate by casting a secret ballot without any interference.

 d) Vote as my conscience tells you.

 e) Express my opinion about the candidates, their campaigns and the issues they talk about with out fear of intimidation.

Remember that rights go with duties. As a voter I must:

 a) Keep my National ID or Passport safely.

 b) Vote whenever the opportunity is presented.

 c) Vote only once in a particular Election

 d) Give other Citizens the chance to vote.

 e) Use my Vote wisely and not sell it for money or any other temporary material gain.

a) Pretence to be unable to read or write so as to be assisted in voting.

 b) Pretence to be visually impared or suffering from other disabillity so as to be assisted in voting.

 c) Forgery or defacing of election materials.

 d) Defacing or Destroying ballot paper or election material.

 e) Attempt to buy or sell ballot papers.

 f) Being found in possession of ballot papers, marked or unmarked.

 g) Inserting or putting anything other than ballot paper in the ballot box.

 h) Removal of any election material from a polling station.

 i) Interference with any Election material, used or intended to be used for an Election.

 j) Attempts to print a ballot paper

 k) Making any mark on any ballot paper issued to any person other than to oneself.

 l) Attempts to vote when not entitled to.

 m) Attempts to vote more than once.

 n) Interference with a voter in casting of his vote in secret.
For any of the mentioned offences, one is liable of conviction to a fine not exceeding one million Kenya Shillings or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding six years or to both.

Once my details are confirmed on the register, I am issued with ballot papers to cast my vote. The Polling Clerk gives me the ballot papers, I look at the ballot paper keenly to ensure that it bears IEBC validating rubber stamp. If the ballot paper is not rubber stamped, my vote will be rejected.

I take my ballot paper inside the voting screen so that no one can see whom I am voting for. There is a pen there for me to use. I open the ballot to see the names of all the candidates. I find the name of the candidate I want. I make an X in the space beside the name of the candidate I choose. The X is my vote. If I make a mistake, I can take my ballot back and ask for another one.

I fold my ballot to keep my vote a secret and cast it in the ballot box. I am keen to ensure that I place the ballot paper in a ballot box with corresponding/ similar colour. Then I go to the polling clerk who will mark my left small finger with indelible ink. I have just voted! I collect my ID/Passport and leave the polling station.
Look at examples of valid ballot papers
Look at examples of rejected ballot papers
Remind your friends to vote by sending them an invite
Remember to vote in these elections!
Report an election offence to the authorities
Search for a Polling Station or Registration Centre
Search for a Political Party in Kenya
